The CT at 90 cm appears to have fractured on a thin layer of faceted crystals that I did not detect in the profile. The thick slab sitting on top of this thin layer of crystals released as SP. This layer of faceted crystals appears to be nested in what I have identified as layer 4 and was my layer of greatest concern.

The CT at 90 cm fractured on a thin layer of faceted crystals that I did not detect in the profile. The thick slab sitting on top of this thin layer of crystals released as SP. This layer of faceted crystals appears to be be nested in what I originally identified as a much larger layer designated layer 4. The thin layer of crystals bisecting this large slab was my layer of greatest concern.
Open slope un-skied all season.
ECTP35-Xtra Force @25cm on FC above crust and column slid into pit.

Below treeline terrain is thin and weak. This location has very weak snow near the surface resting on a relatively hard wind slab on top of depth hoar. The wind slab can hold a much larger load and if there is ever a big slab put on top could fail at the ground.

There appeared to be several additional weak layers deeper in the profile detected by pole probing. The pit location was on the lee side of a small mound that received a lot of wind transported deposition. The location seemed a reasonable representation of the type of wind loading likely to be present over the regular Skinner hut approach. We choose to ski out the ridge instead.
Observers: GB, GF challenging site with multiple laminite MFcr in upper 50cm of snow Site: open boulder field below skiers left side of oreo cliff

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Storm snow is still adjusting. 50cm since 2/6, sits on 10cm from 2/4 above MF crust and NSFC below. Density inversion in the newest storm snow is still sensitive and reactive to moderate taps in stability tests. Lots of snow in a short time = unstable..but settling.

20 cm snow in last 24 hours (more in spots). Though snowpack is strong above old basal facets, the newest snow isn't boonding well yet, and is sloughing on steep terrain. Wind slabs also present on various aspects and ridglines (notice NW winds). Skied slopes after ski cutting steep entrances.
Upper new snow had several layers fracturing between storm interfaces.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: pit dug right under gzx exploder #1 so the snowpack is the former bed surface of multiple explosive triggered avalanches

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent activity on similar slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Triggered this avalanche while approaching low angle terrain from top of slope to dig a pit. AFr-SS-R2-D2-S. 100' wide x 70' long, Crown varied 1-3' thick. **Lower ECTP21 on facets broke when I put shovel behind column to shear off first ECTN. Recorded as ECTP because it collapsed and slid with little extra force when shovel was placed behind column (estimated ECTP 21).**
Total depth was 265cm

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Collapsing, localized; Recent activity on similar slopes

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Best results this season on S. aspect. I tried to pick a representative location, but HS varied across slope from 95 cm to 155 cm, with estimated average HS of 130cm.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Below treeline snowpack still has depth hoar but where HS is greater than 150cm it will take a very big load for failure. Lower elevations below treeline have closer to 1 meter HS and in these locations the entire pack is much weaker.

Pit_Observation.activities: Poor pit location
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry
Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Tapped ECT and Compression up to 30 without fail. Using a shovel to wedge the back of the column, we did get failure on the Compression and ECT columns at 90 cm above ground at the top of the 4F layer. For the compression test, the block sheared ad popped out with a bit of energy. The ECT failed at exactly the same depth and propagated across the entire 1 meter wide column with little/no energy.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Temps never dipped below 0 C last night. Instability test results were in the top 20 cm; will become more reactive as temps increase. Layer of concern has three lemons: facets, hardness step, and grain size step; possible trigger in shallow snow

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Total depth was 270cm. Rain event that evening created new 1.5cm crust on surface.
Northerly aspects are generally deep and strong. Storm snow instabilities and NSFC buried 50-80cm below the surface are becoming less and less reactive.
